values.label: Limited neck strength  requires support for the head.
Presence of Palmar Grasp Reflex. Baby closes his/her fist when a small object is placed in his/her palm.
Remains Alert 15-30% of the Time. Sleeps a significant part of the day.
Presence of All Primitive Reflexes. Involuntary movements that help them navigate early life e.g., sucking, palmar, grasp, plantar, Moro's, rooting, etc.
Presence of Plantar Reflex. A gentle stroke on the sole of the foot causes flexion of the toes.
Presence of Sucking Reflex. Child sucks anything that touches the roof of their mouth.
Presence of Moro's Reflex. The baby stretches his/her arms back and then retracts arms back as a reaction to a sudden loss of support or a sudden noise.
Presence of Rooting Reflex. Baby turns his/her head towards anything that strokes his/her cheek.
Expects regular feeding intervals.
Deliberately cries to ask for help.
Produces basic high pitch noises.
Communicates Through Crying. Whimpers and cries are the primary means of communication.
Curious about human faces and objects with circles.
Perceives light, its intensity and movement.
Perceives changes in temperatures.
Sleeping, crying and eating patterns are still disorganized.
Responds to the human voice by looking at the person talking.
Extends arms and opens hands  hands remain clenched in a fist most of the time.
Tries to maintain head upright for a few seconds.
Palmar grasp reflex still active  grabs others' fingers firmly if put in the palm of the hand.
Moves closed hand towards objects.
Opens hand when you put an object in it  automatically closes it.
Studies and explores the movements of hands.
Starts developing a variety of coos and  gurgles (crying remains the main form of communication).
Identifies Human Voice, can differentiate  from other sounds.
Makes eye contact.
Startles as a reaction to certain noises.
Identifies Human Voice, can differentiate  from other sounds.
Reacts to the presence of a person by moving his/her arms and legs, breathing heavily or gesturing.
Expresses emotions, like pleasure, anxiety and excitement.
Prefers people over objects.
Neck Strengthening. lifts head for a few seconds when prone.
Applies pressure when feet are against something firm.
Able to make a variety of head and neck movements.
Attempts to lean on forearms when lying on the stomach.
Vigorous Limb Movement. moves arms and legs enthusiastically.
Likes to be carried and maintained in an upright position.
Palmar grasp reflex starts to disappear and hands stay open for longer periods of time.
Opens and closes hands.
Hits objects hanging near fingertips.
Brings hand to mouth.
Expresses interest or excitement about something (e.g., feeding) through random arm and leg movements.
Reacts to sounds with a combination of  sighs, coos or gurgles.
Sound Seeking. Looks for the source of a sound by turning head and neck.
Looks at people's faces with increased attention.
Improved cross-sense coordination (e.g., sucks bottle and looks at it simultaneously while feeding).
Pays attention to voices and unfamiliar noises.
Enjoys listening when someone sings.
Stops sucking or other activities to listen to new noises.
Extends arms toward bottle or breast.
Seeks attention when parents are nearby.
Displays a varied range of expressions to show mood.
Crying frequency starts to decrease.
Head Control. raises head 45 degrees while lying face down and can hold head straight when held in a vertical position.
Turns head in all directions while lying on pillows or other types of support.
Begins to develop hand-eye coordination.
Grabs Objects. sometimes able to grab and shake items with hands  still lacks accuracy.
Pulls hanging objects and brings them to mouth.
Imitation. can mimic some simple actions (e.g., opening and closing eyes and sticking out tongue).
Explores face using hands, discovering different features, including eyes and mouth.
Looks at objects and tries to put them in mouth.
Combines gurgles and vocal play (isolated vowel-like and consonant-like sounds).
Pays attention to the sounds of words and listens to adult conversations.
Looks closely while opening and closing own hands.
Identifies and shows interest in smelling different types of scents.
Reacts excitedly when music starts  might protest when it stops.
Smiles Often. easily and spontaneously.
Responds positively to touch.
Still Primarily Sleeping. at this age babies sleep around 15 hours per day (including naps).
Sleeping, feeding and activity patterns begin to be   established.
Front to Back Roll.when face-down, might be able to move side to side until rolls over onto back (between months 4 and 5).
Makes vigorous swimming-like movements.
Able to put feet in mouth and suck toes.
Ulnar Palmar Grasp. grasps objects using outer or ulnar side of the palm without using the thumb.
Two-Hand Hold. can hold objects with both hands.
Reaches for objects with one or both hands.
Wants to touch, grab, manipulate, shake and taste objects.
Holds and drops objects but still not able to pick up.
More deliberate movements  anticipatory adaptive movements begin (i.e., the baby extends arms and opens hands when seeing a desired toy).
Explores physical properties of objects (their weight, shape) and other characteristics, such as position and distance.
Interested in producing and imitating new sounds.
Might direct sounds toward nearby people, objects and toys.
Eye-Body Coordination. increased capability (e.g., looks at an object and tries to reach it).
Deliberately turns head toward an object.
Enjoys bath time, lifts head when lying on his/her back in the tub.
Feeding and sleeping schedules are increasingly established.
Social Skills. engages with other people  with preference for parents  smiles more openly.
Actively looks around when in a new place, exploring surroundings.
Laughs as a method of socializing  cries, when playtime is over or stopped.
Learns that parents and caregivers respond to crying  may use it to get attention.
Core Strength. lying face down, can adopt a superman-like position (arms and knees lifted, back arched).
Able to lift chest up with arms when prone.
Able to stay in a sitting position for a few seconds without assistance.
Turns head freely in both directions.
Nearly always uses a single arm to reach for something, rather than using both.
Palmar Grasp. grasps objects with the center of the palm, still without using the thumb.
Extends arm out to reach for an object that has fallen.
Able to quickly reach out and grab an object of interest.
May have strong enough grip to lift self from lying down to seated while holding onto a stick being lifted by a caregiver.
Imitation. purposely tries to mimic simple sounds and movements.
Able to remain alert for nearly two continuous hours.
Recognizes frequently used objects or toys.
Understands the difference between a human face and non-human objects and animals.
Leans body to look for an object that has dropped.
Recognizes immediate family, may get upset with strangers.
Improved vocal play  transitioning to  babbling.
Repeats simple sounds like ba, da, ca just to hear them.
Displays a broader variety of changes in volume and tone when talking.
Hand-eye coordination improves  arms and hands follow eyes when reaching for objects.
Able to visually track fast-moving objects
Able to hold the bottle with one or two hands.
Sleeps through the night, which at this age means 8-12 hours.
Abrupt changes of mood, primarily alternating between happiness, fussiness and sadness.
Sitting. can remain in a seated position for limited periods of time, using own arms as support.
Rolling and Moving. Able to roll over, turn and pivot in all directions.
Starts moving using army crawl (not all babies do it).
Able to turn and then reach out in order to grab an object of interest.
Strong control of head movements.
Radial Palmar Grasp: Objects are secured using the radial side of the palm, the thumb, the index and middle fingers  all other fingers remain flexed.
Clapping: Might start clapping hands (between months 6 and 9).
Able to manipulate, hit and take objects to his mouth.
High level of interest in toys that produce sounds like bells, music boxes and rattles.
Begins to Recognize Own Name: Reacts when called by name.
Might be able to use a toy as a tool to grab another one.
Examines objects for a long period of time.
Explores body with mouth and hands.
Reduplicated Babbling: Repetition of the same consonant-vowel syllable (e.g., 'baba, 'mama')  doesn't understand meaning.
Able to control opening and closing of the vocal tract, necessary for production of consonant and vowel sounds.
Able to differentiate distance, understanding when objects are near or far.
If baby is eating solids, enjoys playing with food and displays interest  in feeding self using fingers.
Knows “No”: Starting to understand the meaning of 'no' by recognizing the tone of the voice.
Gets excited when realizes that it is playtime.
Begins to interact with his/her own image in a mirror, although he/she will not recognize it as herself/himself yet  he/she will try to softly knock or touch his/her reflection.
Displays happiness in enjoyable situations and disapproval in those that are not.
Becomes difficult for parents to get the baby to do things the child does not want to do, even with significant encouragement.
Strong Sitting. displays good balance while seated without using arms as support  bends forward and backward to reach for a nearby object.
While sitting, able to rock and bounce on bottom.
Attempts to get up on hands and knees to get into a crawling position.
Grasping Objects. can hold two objects simultaneously, one in each hand  can bang them together.
Raking Grasp. uses index and middle fingers to rake nearby objects closer.
Experiments with hands, moving them in different ways, grasping and dropping objects.
Higher ability to focus  demonstrates curiosity about people.
Recognizes name and reacts when called.
Expands variety of consonant-vowel syllables, but often repeats the same syllable multiple times before moving to another.
Experiments with taking turns to talk, as if having an actual two-person conversation.
Hearing fuels curiosity  pays close attention to subtle sounds like the ticking of a clock.
Begins to develop strong preferences for different food tastes.
Maintains interest in playing for longer periods of time  increased level of engagement.
Waves goodbye (between months 7 and 10).
Separation anxiety is often expressed through fear of strangers or any separation from mother.
Might feel compassion when someone cries  occasionally might join in crying or may imitate someone's mood.
Pushes away or rejects something unwanted.
Sits Alone: Can remain in a steady seated position for several minutes without using arms as support.
Sits Up: Able to get into a sitting position from lying down, face up or face down.
Once in a standing position (likely with help), needs assistance to go back to a sitting position.
Can maintain a standing position by using furniture as support  still can't stand up without help.
Radial Digital Grasp: Grasps objects using index finger, middle finger and thumb.
Able to grab and manipulate two objects simultaneously, one in each hand.
Has a mental model of the human face and becomes interested in the way it looks and its different forms of expression (e.g., happy face, sad face, etc.).

Can solve simple problems and combine small sequences of actions or behaviors to create a new result or reach the same result in a different way (e.g., kicking a hanging toy to be able to grab it)  this skill forms the basis for learning.
Attempts to imitate noises or sounds produced by objects (e.g., 'boom!').
Might start combining more than one consonant-vowel syllables when babbling.
Listens carefully to conversations and songs, understanding the difference in tones.
Easily distracted  more interested in discovering and exploring surroundings than in things like eating.
Performs actions to get applause.
Becomes proactive about starting playtime.
Becomes protective of self and possessions  might fight over a toy.
Better understands people's moods (e.g., gets happy when everybody is happy, gets anxious when there is stress).
Deliberately chooses toys with which to play.
Prefers to play close to mother.
Pull to Stand. starts using furniture to try to stand, still needs help.
Crawling. able to crawl (between months 8-10)  can do it forward or backward at the beginning.
Goes from crawling to a sitting position without significant effort.
Inferior Pincer Grasp. grasps objects between index finger and thumb but uses the entire surface of each finger, rather than only the fingertips, to hold the object.
Able to grab thin objects (e.g., a shoelace). Able to carry two small objects in one hand.
Voluntarily drops objects, although lacks control to place objects on a surface gently.
Can open drawers and will explore contents.
Uses hands in different ways  for example, uses one as support and the other to manipulate an object.
Stacks similar objects, fitting one thing into another (e.g., plastic cups).
Object Permanence. is able to recover an object that has been hidden as he/she observes.
Anticipates a reward for the successful completion of a task or order.
Able to hold several ideas in mind at the same time (e.g., can communicate with mom while playing).
Gets bored more easily (e.g., from a toy, from playing the same game or from the same stimulus).
Becomes aware of heights, which might create fear.
Variegated Babbling. more sophisticated form of babbling that combines different consonant-vowel syllables instead of repeating the same one.
Says 'No' while shaking head side to side..
Understands individuality within a group (can pick one toy within a group, understands that they are separate toys vs. a single entity).
While getting dressed, increasingly helps by moving and preparing his/her arms and legs as needed.
Increased awareness of self  increasingly aware of social approval or disapproval.
Imitates gestures, facial expressions and sounds.
Displays a broader set of moods (frustrated, sad, happy, angry, excited, etc.).
Picks one or a few toys as favorites.
Demonstrates fear in new places.
Attempts to Cruise.while standing supported by furniture, tries to place one foot in front of the other to move.
Sits from Standing.able to move from standing up to sitting on the floor.
Will try to stand up in different ways, using different types of support.
Perfect crawling, with improved speed and form.
Climbs onto and off of chairs and other furniture.
Pincer Grasp. grasps small objects using the tips of the index finger and thumb.
Places objects into and removes them from a cup, box or other type of container.
Able to remove a loose top from a container.
Tries to turn the pages in a cardboard children's book, often turning more than one page at a time.
Reach Behind. seeks and reaches for an object that is behind self without needing to see it.
Continues to learn about objects and their properties (e.g., crinkles paper, makes noise with boxes, listens to the tick tock of the clock).
Understands Object Names. associates meaning between words and the things to which they refer.
Understands some simple instructions (e.g., pick up a ball or crawl to mom).
Can imitate inflections, the rhythm of a conversation and facial expressions more accurately than the words in the conversation.
Increasingly interested in playing and exploring the world  mealtime becomes increasingly challenging (often not interested in eating).
Imitates movements and games of other children and adults.
Searches for images of nearby objects in the mirror.
Enjoys Peek-a-boo style games.
Increased Dependence on Mother. separation anxiety can be high in next 4-8 months.
Might deliberately decide not to cooperate sometimes.
Cruising. able to walk around by holding on to furniture.
Solo Standing. might be able to let go  of support and remain standing (between months 11 and 13).
Crawling Up and Down Stairs. might be able to climb up and down steps on all fours  will go backwards to go down.
Able to walk steadily while holding an adult 's  hand (between months 11 and 13).
Able to assemble things better  more interested in building instead of just destroying things (e.g., block towers).
Might use armpit or mouth to carry a third object when hands are each carrying something.
Body Parts. points to a few body parts when asked.
Uses objects as means to achieve goals  for example, uses a small chair as a walker to be able to walk around.
Conversational Babbling.babbling starts,to resemble talking as the baby plays with intonation and different talking patterns .
Able to pronounce some small words through imitation.
Can take off socks  increasingly collaborates when getting dressed/undressed.
Feeding might become more challenging, as the baby's curiosity and need for independence increases (i.e., may want to feed self).
Displays many emotions and recognizes them when displayed by other people.
Enjoys playing with water in the sink or during bath time.
Very interested in any activity performed by an adult.
